STATIC_heading.text: ABBREVIATIONS

STATIC_table.text:
ABGsarterial blood gasesNSCLCnon-small cell lung cancer
AFBacid-fast bacillus—the type of organism that causes tuberculosisO2oxygen
ARDSacute respiratory distress syndrome— severe, sudden lung injury caused by acute illnessOSAobstructive sleep apnea
BALbronchoalveolar lavagePaCO2carbon dioxide partial pressure—measure of the amount of carbon dioxide in arterial blood
BronchbronchoscopyPaO2oxygen partial pressure—a measure of the amount of oxygen in arterial blood
CFcystic fibrosisPCPPneumocystis pneumonia—a type of pneumonia seen in patients with AIDS or other immunosuppression
CO2carbon dioxidePEpulmonary embolism
COPDchronic obstructive pulmonary disease— airway obstruction associated with emphysema and chronic bronchitisPEpositive expiratory pressure—mechanical ventilator strategy in which the patient takes a deep breath and then exhales through a device that resists air flow (helps refill underventilated areas of the lung)
CPAPcontinuous positive airway pressurePEEPpositive end-expiratory pressure— common mechanical ventilator setting in which airway pressure is maintained above atmospheric pressure
CPRcardiopulmonary resuscitation—three basic steps (CAB): C, c irculation restored by external cardiac compression; A, airway opened by tilting the head; B, breathing restored by mouth-to-mouth breathingPFTspulmonary function tests
C&Sculture and sensitivity testing (of sputum)PNDparoxysmal nocturnal dyspnea
CTPAcomputed tomography pulmonary angiogramPNDpurified protein derivative—substance used in a tuberculosis test
CT-PEChest CT for pulmonary emboliRDSrespiratory distress syndrome—in the newborn infant; marked by dyspnea and cyanosis and related to absence of surfactant (lubricating substance that permits normal expansion of lungs); also called hyaline membrane disease
CXRchest x-ray [film]RLLright lower lobe (of lung)
DLCOdiffusion capacity of the lung for carbon monoxideRMLright middle lobe (of lung)
DOEdyspnea on exertionRMLrespiratory syncytial virus—common cause of bronchiolitis, bronchopneumonia, and the common cold, especially in children (in tissue culture, forms syncytia or giant cells, so that cytoplasm flows together)
DPTdiphtheria, pertussis, tetanus—toxoids for vaccination of infants, to provide immunity to these diseasesRULright upper lobe (of lung)
EBUSendobronchial ultrasoundRVresidual volume—amount of air remaining in lungs at the end of maximal expiration
FEV1forced expiratory volume in 1 secondSABAshort-acting beta agonist (for relief of asthma symptoms)
FVCforced vital capacity—amount of gas that can be forcibly and rapidly exhaled after a full inspirationSCLCsmall cell lung cancer
ICUintensive care unitSOBshortness of breath
LLLleft lower lobe (of lung)TBtuberculosis
LULleft upper lobe (of lung)TLCtotal lung capacity—volume of gas in the lungs at the end of maximal inspiration; equals VC plus RV
MACMycobacterium avium complex—the cause of a noncontagious lung infection related to tuberculosisURIupper respiratory infection
MDImetered-dose inhaler—used to deliver aerosolized medications to patientsVTtidal volume—amount of air inhaled and exhaled during a normal ventilation
  VATSvideo-assisted thoracic surgery (thoracoscopy)
  VCvital capacity—the maximum volume of
air expelled from the lung after taking
the deepest possible breath
  V/Q scanventilation-perfusion scan—radioactive test of lung ventilation and blood perfusion throughout the lung capillaries (lung scan)
